Tighter Regret Analysis and Optimization of Online Federated Learning

DohyeokÂ Kwon,Â , JonghwanÂ Park,Â  and SongnamÂ Hong D. Kwon and S. Hong are with the Department of Electronic Engineering, Hanyang University, Seoul, 04763, Korea.
E-mail: {kwon1585,snhong}@hanyang.ac.kr J. Park is with the Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Southern California, CA, 90089, USA.
E-mail: jonghwan@usc.edu
Abstract

In federated learning (FL), it is commonly assumed that all data are placed at clients in the beginning of machine learning (ML) optimization (i.e., offline learning). However, in many real-world applications, it is expected to proceed in an online fashion. To this end, online FL (OFL) has been introduced, which aims at learning a sequence of global models from decentralized streaming data such that the so-called cumulative regret is minimized. Combining online gradient descent and model averaging, in this framework, FedOGD is constructed as the counterpart of FedSGD in FL. While it can enjoy an optimal sublinear regret, FedOGD suffers from heavy communication costs. In this paper, we present a communication-efficient method (named OFedIQ) by means of intermittent transmission (enabled by client subsampling and periodic transmission) and quantization. For the first time, we derive the regret bound that captures the impact of data-heterogeneity and the communication-efficient techniques. Through this, we efficiently optimize the parameters of OFedIQ such as sampling rate, transmission period, and quantization levels. Also, it is proved that the optimized OFedIQ can asymptotically achieve the performance of FedOGD while reducing the communication costs by 99%percent9999\%. Via experiments with real datasets, we demonstrate the effectiveness of the optimized OFedIQ.

Index Terms:
Online learning, federated learning, distributed optimization, streaming learning, regret analysis.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is an emerging framework for distributed and privacy-preserving machine learning (ML), in which a central server coordinates ML optimization with a massive number of clients without directly sharing training data stored in the decentralized clients (i.e., local data) [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]. In FL, the clients train local models separately from local data and the central server constructs a global model only using the aggregated local models [6]. Specifically, a global model is learned by performing the two steps iteratively: i) local model optimizations (usually via stochastic gradient descent (SGD)) at each client; ii) global model optimization (e.g., model averaging) at the central server. There are myriads of applications such as ML from wearable devices [7], location-based services [8], and human activity recognition [9].

Recently, numerous FL methods have been proposed. FedSGD was introduced in [6], where a global model is optimized via local stochastic gradient descent (SGD) at clients and model averaging at a central server. Also, in [10], the convergence analysis of FedSGD was provided for both cases of identical and heterogeneous data. Incorporating client subsampling (or partial participation) and periodic averaging into FedSGD, the de facto optimization method (named FedAvg) was presented in [6], which has lower communication costs than FedSGD. In [11], a communication-efficient FL method (named FedPAQ) was proposed by integrating a stochastic quantization into FedAvg. To sophisticate a quantization method, vector quantizations suitable for FL were proposed in [12, 13, 14]. Also, an enhanced gradient-quantization technique, called Lazily Aggregated Quantized (LAQ) gradient, was presented in [15]. Interestingly, it was shown in [16, 17] that FedAvg suffers from the so-called â€˜client-driftâ€™ when the degree of data heterogeneity is high (i.e., non-IID data), resulting in unstable and slower convergence. This problem becomes more serious as the fraction of participating clients becomes smaller. Many works have put much effort into addressing the above problem. SCAFFOLD [17] and Variance Reduced Local-SGD (VRL-SGD) [18] employed extra control variates to accelerate the convergence by reducing the variance of stochastic gradients. FedProx [19] added a proximal term to each local optimizations in order to suppress the discrepancy among the local models. FedNova [20] normalized the magnitude of local updates across the clients in the network so that the model averaging less distracts the global loss.

1.1 Related Works

In most of the existing FL works, it is commonly assumed that features (or data) do not possess an associated inherent ordering (i.e., non-streaming data) and accordingly, all data samples are placed at clients in the beginning of ML optimization (i.e., offline learning). Existing FL methods, thus, have paid little attention to ML optimization from continuous streaming (or time-series) data. In many real-world applications, however, ML tasks are expected to be performed in an online fashion, wherein data samples are generated as a function of time and clients have to predict a label (or make a decision) upon receiving an incoming data. To handle such tasks, online FL (OFL) has been introduced in [21] by combining online learning (OL) (or streaming learning) [22] and FL. The goal of OFL is to seek a sequence of global models (or functions) in real time from continuous streaming data arriving at decentralized clients [21, 23]. At each time step, an up-to-date function is used to predict the label of newly incoming (previously unseen) data. The major difference between OFL methods and the aforementioned FL methods(e.g., FedAvg [6], FedPAQ[11], SCAFFOLD [17], FedProx [19], and FedNova [20]) is in the objective of local updates. While FL methods aim at seeking a sole global model that minimizes a global loss function, OFL methods aim at seeking a sequence of global models that minimizes the so-called cumulative regret (see SectionÂ 2) for details). Because of such difference, the existing FL methods may not ensure an optimal sublinear regret (i.e., an asymptotic optimality) for OFL. This opens up the necessity of new researches for OFL.

Very recently in [21], an OFL method based on random feature-based multiple kernels (named eM-KOFL) was presented and its asymptotic optimality was proved via martingale argument. This work was mainly focused on dealing with multiple kernels in a communication-efficient way. Especially when a single-kernel is considered, vanilla method (named FedOGD) was constructed and analyzed, which can be immediately applied to deep neural network (DNN)-based methods. Note that FedOGD can be regarded as the counterpart of FedSGD [6] in FL. While it can enjoy an optimal sublinear regret, FedOGD suffers from heavy communication costs. A communication-efficient OFL method (named PSO-Fed) was proposed in [23], where clients and a central server exchange a fraction of their model parameters: however, no regret analysis was conducted. These two methods employed online gradient descent (OGD) (which is commonly used for OL) as the underlying online optimization method to the clients. Leveraging online mirror descent (OMD) and periodic averaging, FedOMD was presented in [24]. Note that when a widely-used Euclidean distance is adopted as Bregman divergence, OMD is reduced to OGD [25]. It was proved that FedOMD can enjoy an optimal subliner regret. To the best of our knowledge, there is no additional OFL method with an analytical performance guarantee.

We emphasize that compared with FL, OFL researches are at an infancy level. In particular, the existing regret analyses have not considered the impact of the fundamental communication-efficient techniques (e.g., client subsampling, periodic transmission, and quantization), and data-heterogeneity over time and across clients. This is the motivation of our work since such analysis would be the stepping stone for the research of OFL.

1.2 Contributions

In this paper, OFL is investigated in terms of constructing a communication-efficient method and tighter regret analysis. We improve the communication-efficiency of the baseline method (FedOGD) via two fundamental techniques such as intermittent transmission of model updates and quantization of updated gradients (see Fig. 1). The former directly reduces the number of transmissions (or active communication channels) and the latter diminishes the number of transmitted bits per each active channel. The proposed method is referred to as Online Federated learning method with Intermittent transmission and Quantization (OFedIQ). Herein, intermittent transmission is enabled by client subsampling (a.k.a. partial client participation) and periodic transmission (a.k.a. periodic averaging), which stand for the infrequent transmissions across clients and over time steps, respectively. Our major contributions are summarized as follows.

  • â€¢

    We derive tighter theory for OFL through a novel regret analysis. Our analysis is more rigorous than the existing ones such as the regret analysis of centralized OL [22, 26, 27] and the regret analyses of distributed and federated OL [28, 21, 29, 24]. This is because our regret bound can reflect for the first time the effects of data-heterogeneity and the communication-efficient techniques (e.g., client subsampling, periodic transmission, quantization) on learning accuracy.

  • â€¢

    Through our analysis, we prove that OFedIQ over Tğ‘‡T time steps can enjoy an optimal sublinear regret ğ’ªâ€‹(T)ğ’ªğ‘‡{\cal O}(\sqrt{T}) for any dataset (up to a constant), where the constant is bigger as data-heterogeneity grows. Namely, OFedIQ has the same asymptotic performance as FedOGD (i.e., the performance-limit) while significantly reducing the communication costs (e.g., about 99%percent9999\% reduction).

  • â€¢

    For practical non-asymptotic cases, it is required to optimize the key parameters of OFedIQ such as sampling rate, transmission period, and quantization levels. Leveraging our regret bound, we efficiently tackle such optimization problem, yielding almost closed-form solutions (see Algorithm 3). Given target communication costs, the proposed Algorithm 3 provides the optimal parameters of OFedIQ with respect to maximizing the asymptotic learning accuracy.

  • â€¢

    Via experiments with real datasets, we demonstrate the superiority of the optimized OFedIQ on online classification and regression tasks. It can almost achieve the performance of FedOGD (i.e., the performance limit of communication-efficient OFL methods) while reducing the communication costs by 99%percent9999\%. Also, our method can outperform the benchmark methods such as OFedAvg and FedOMD for all datasets. These results suggest the practicality of the optimized OFedIQ.

1.3 Outline and Notations

The remaining part of this paper is organized as follows. In SectionÂ 2, we formally define the objective and learning process of OFL. In SectionÂ 3.2, we introduce the vanilla method (named FedOGD) and enhance its communication-efficiency by means of intermittent transmission and quantization. The resulting method is named OFedIQ. A tighter regret analysis is conducted in SectionÂ 4 and on the basis of this analysis, we efficiently optimize the key parameters of OFedIQ. In SectionÂ 5, we verify the effectiveness of our algorithm via experiments with real datasets. Some concluding remarks are provided in SectionÂ 6.

2 Online Federated Learning (OFL)

We formally define an online federated Learning (OFL) [21, 24, 23]. Recall that in (conventional) FL, ML optimization is tackled under the assumption that each client has access to local data samples offline and such samples are generated statistically. Whereas, OFL is basically formed by combining online learning (OL) and FL. Compared to FL, thus, OFL has the following two major differences:

  • â€¢

    Sequential data acquisition: At every time step, each client has access to newly incoming (previously unseen) data. As in OL [22], there is no statistical assumption on data samples. The detailed description of data acquisition in OFL will be provided in SectionÂ 2.1.

  • â€¢

    Online optimization: Following the principle of OL, the objective of OFL is to learn a sequence of global models ğ°1,ğ°2,â€¦,ğ°Tsubscriptğ°1subscriptğ°2â€¦subscriptğ°ğ‘‡{\bf w}_{1},{\bf w}_{2},...,{\bf w}_{T} in an online fashion such that the so-called cumulative regret is minimized (see SectionÂ 2.2).

Remarkably, due to the aforementioned differences, it is required to conduct a new theoretical analysis for OFL, even if similar techniques in FL are applied.

2.1 Sequential Data Acquisition

We consider a distributed learning framework consisting of Kğ¾K clients indexed by kâˆˆ[K]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾k\in[K] and a central server. At time step tğ‘¡t, the central server broadcasts the up-to-date global model (denoted by ğ°tsubscriptğ°ğ‘¡{\bf w}_{t}) to the Kğ¾K clients. We next focus on the local operations which are performed in a distributed way. At time step tğ‘¡t, each client kâˆˆ[k]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ‘˜k\in[k] starts to update its local model once it receives the true label of ğ±k,tsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜ğ‘¡{\bf x}_{k,t}, denoted by yk,tâˆˆğ’´âŠ†â„subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğ’´â„y_{k,t}\in\mathcal{Y}\subseteq\mathbb{R}. Communication costs (per time step): The communication costs of an OFL method are measured by the number of total transmitted bits of local information (e.g., ğ¦k,tsubscriptğ¦ğ‘˜ğ‘¡{\bf m}_{k,t}â€™s) conveyed from the Kğ¾K clients to the central server (in short, uplink communication costs). Herein, 32-bit quantization is typically assumed to represent a real-value precisely. The communication costs from the central server to the Kğ¾K clients (i.e., downlink communication costs) are not of concern as they are relatively very small due to the broadcasting nature.

    Simultaneously a new local data (ğ±k,t,yk,t)subscriptğ±ğ‘˜ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜ğ‘¡({\bf x}_{k,t},y_{k,t}) is generated at each client kğ‘˜k for âˆ€kâˆˆ[K]for-allğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾\forall k\in[K].

    Each client kâˆˆ[K]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾k\in[K] suffers from the local loss â„’â€‹(fâ€‹(ğ±k,t;ğ°t),yk,t)â„’ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘˜ğ‘¡subscriptğ°ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜ğ‘¡{\cal L}(f({\bf x}_{k,t};{\bf w}_{t}),y_{k,t}), where â„’â€‹(â‹…,â‹…)â„’â‹…â‹…{\cal L}(\cdot,\cdot) is a loss (or cost) function that measures the error between true and predicted labels.

  • â€¢

    Leveraging the local-loss, each client kğ‘˜k optimizes its local model ğ¦k,tsubscriptğ¦ğ‘˜ğ‘¡{\bf m}_{k,t}.

As in (centralized) OL [25, 22, 27, 21], the objective of OFL is to seek a sequence of global models ğ°1,ğ°2,â€¦,ğ°Tsubscriptğ°1subscriptğ°2â€¦subscriptğ°ğ‘‡{\bf w}_{1},{\bf w}_{2},...,{\bf w}_{T} that minimizes the cumulative regret over Tğ‘‡T time steps:

The upper bound on regretTsubscriptregretğ‘‡\mbox{regret}_{T} is referred to as regret bound. This metric compares the cumulative loss of an OFL method with that of the static optimal function in hindsight. We emphasize that due to the sequential optimization nature of OFL protocol, its performance metric in (3) becomes totally different from that of (conventional) FL methods. To be specific, the local steps of FL methods aim at optimizing an objective function such as the expected global loss over local data distributions, whereas those of OFL methods aim at minimizing the cumulative regret in (3). Therefore, it is required to conduct a new analysis for OFL methods even if they are constructed using the well-proven techniques in the existing FL methods. We contribute to this subject.

3 Methods

In this section, we introduce a vanilla method for OFL as the counterpart of FedSGD for FL, and then improve its communication-efficiency by means of intermittent transmission and quantization.

3.1 Vanilla Method: FedOGD

We construct a vanilla method by integrating online gradient descent (OGD) [25] into OFL. This method is named FedOGD (i.e., the de facto algorithm in OFL) as the counterpart of FedSGD in FL [6]. 3.2 Communication-Efficient Method: OFedIQ

To alleviate the heavy communication costs, numerous communication-reduction techniques have been proposed for conventional FL [11, 12, 13, 14]. Among them, the key features can be summarized as follows: (i) client subsampling (a.k.a. partial client participation); ii) periodic transmission (a.k.a. periodic averaging); (iii) quantization. Note that (i) and (ii) enable intermittent transmission, thereby directly reducing the number of transmissions, and (iii) decreases the number of transmitted bits per communication-channel. We first describe the three key features in the context of OFL (see Fig.Â 1).

Client subsampling: In OFL, there are lots of clients (e.g., smart phone users) communicating with a central server via an uplink communication channel. At every time step, thus, it is impractical to have all clients participating in OFL protocol due to the extremely heavy communication costs. As in (conventional) FL methods [6, 11], client subsampling, where a small fraction of clients are participated in OFL protocol at every time step, is necessary for OFL methods. To that end, we in this paper adopt the probabilistic client subsampling: each client kâˆˆ[K]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾k\in[K] can be sampled (or participated) with probability 0<pk<10subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜10<p_{k}<1 independently at every time step and from other clients, where pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k} indicates the sampling rate (or participation probability). Note that various pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k}â€™s can take into account system-heterogeneity since higher probabilities can be assigned to the clients with higher computation capabilities or communication capacities. We remark that this probabilistic approach is required for the compactness of tighter regret analysis while any approach can be immediately applied to the proposed OFL method. Throughout the paper, ğ’®tâŠ†[K]subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ¾{\cal S}_{t}\subseteq[K] represents the index subset of participating (or sampled) clients at time step tğ‘¡t. In convention, full client participation implies that pk=1subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜1p_{k}=1 for âˆ€kâˆˆ[K]for-allğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾\forall k\in[K] (i.e., ğ’®t=[K]subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ¾{\cal S}_{t}=[K] for âˆ€tfor-allğ‘¡\forall t). Obviously, when pk<1subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜1p_{k}<1 for some kğ‘˜k, ğ’®tâŠ†[K]subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ¾{\cal S}_{t}\subseteq[K] is a random variable due to our probabilistic modeling, namely, a time-varying client subsampling is considered. When our client subsampling is applied, the communication cost can be reduced to 32â€‹Dâ€‹âˆ‘k=1Kpk32ğ·superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜32D\sum_{k=1}^{K}p_{k} bits in average. In the homogeneous setting with pk=psubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘p_{k}=p for âˆ€kfor-allğ‘˜\forall k, they can be simplified as 32â€‹pâ€‹Kâ€‹D32ğ‘ğ¾ğ·32pKD bits in average

Periodic transmission: Periodic transmission is one of the key techniques to reduce the communication costs in FL [11]. However, in OFL, this method might degrade the performance (i.e., the cumulative regret in (3)) as a new global model ğ°t+1subscriptğ°ğ‘¡1{\bf w}_{t+1} should be constructed at every time step. This question will be addressed in SectionÂ 4 based on our tighter regret analysis. Assuming the transmission period Lâ‰¥1ğ¿1L\geq 1, each client kâˆˆ[K]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾k\in[K] sends the local information ğ¦k,tsubscriptğ¦ğ‘˜ğ‘¡{\bf m}_{k,t} to the central server at every Lğ¿L time steps. Due to the infrequent transmission, a sequence of learned global models is obtained as

For example, during the Lğ¿L time steps 2â€‹L+1â‰¤tâ‰¤3â€‹L2ğ¿1ğ‘¡3ğ¿2L+1\leq t\leq 3L, the identical global model ğ°2â€‹L+1subscriptğ°2ğ¿1{\bf w}_{2L+1} (which is updated at time 2â€‹L2ğ¿2L) is used. Generally, for any time step tâˆˆ[T]ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡t\in[T], the corresponding global model is equal to ğ°ÏˆLâ€‹(t)subscriptğ°subscriptğœ“ğ¿ğ‘¡{\bf w}_{\psi_{L}(t)}. While the communication costs are reduced to 32â€‹Kâ€‹D/L32ğ¾ğ·ğ¿32KD/L, the use of outdated global model might degrade learning accuracy. Thus, the transmission period Lğ¿L should be carefully determined by considering the tradeoff between learning accuracy and communication overhead. On the basis of our analysis, we will give the answer to this question in SectionÂ 4.2.1.

Quantization: To reduce the communication costs, it is crucial to decrease the number of transmitted bits for conveying the local information ğ¦k,tsubscriptğ¦ğ‘˜ğ‘¡{\bf m}_{k,t}â€™s. This can be done from the quantization of the information ğ¦k,tsubscriptğ¦ğ‘˜ğ‘¡{\bf m}_{k,t} [11, 12, 13, 14]. In this paper, a qğ‘q-bit quantizer Qqâ€‹(â‹…)subscriptğ‘„qâ‹…Q_{\rm q}(\cdot) is assumed. Note that any scalar or vector quantizer can be applied to the proposed OFL method. For our analysis and experiments, a specific quantizer will be defined.

Incorporating the aforementioned techniques into FedOGD, we present a communication-efficient OFL method, named Online Federated learning with Intermittent transmission and Quantization (OFedIQ). The proposed method performs with the following two steps (see Fig.Â 1):

i) Local update: At time step tâˆˆ[T]ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡t\in[T], each client kâˆˆ[K]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾k\in[K] optimizes the local model by leveraging the incoming data (ğ±k,t,yk,t)subscriptğ±ğ‘˜ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜ğ‘¡({\bf x}_{k,t},y_{k,t}) and the up-to-date global model. First, according to the time step tğ‘¡t, the parameter of a local function is updated via either globally or locally:

Moreover, via client subsampling, every client kğ‘˜k can have a chance to participate in the global update with probability pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k}. That is, at every Lğ¿L time step, each client kğ‘˜k can send the local information ğ¦k,tsubscriptğ¦ğ‘˜ğ‘¡{\bf m}_{k,t} to the central server with probability pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k}.

The overall procedures are summarized in Algorithm 2.

Recall that the communication costs of the vanilla method (FedOGD) are equal to 32â€‹Kâ€‹D32ğ¾ğ·32KD bits. Whereas, the communication costs of OFedIQ are reduced to pâ€‹Kâ€‹Dâ€‹logâ¡(q)/Lğ‘ğ¾ğ·ğ‘ğ¿pKD\log{(q)}/L bits. On the basis of our regret analysis, the parameters pğ‘p, Lğ¿L, and qğ‘q will be efficiently optimized in SectionÂ 4.2.

4 Regret Analysis

In this section, we conduct a tighter regret analysis for OFL methods in SectionÂ 3.2. Our analysis is non-trivial extensions of the existing ones such as the centralized OL [22, 26, 27] and decentralized OL [27, 28, 21, 29, 24]. For the first time, our regret bound can reflect the impact of data-heterogeneity and the key communication-reduction techniques such as client subsampling, periodic transmission, and quantization. Contrary to the existing OL analyses [22, 26, 29, 27, 28, 21], we do not assume the bounded gradient (a.k.a. GğºG-Lipschitz continuous) such as â€–âˆ‡â„’â€‹(fâ€‹(ğ±k,t;ğ°),yk,t)â€–2â‰¤Gsuperscriptnormâˆ‡â„’ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğ°subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜ğ‘¡2ğº\|\nabla{\cal L}(f({\bf x}_{k,t};{\bf w}),y_{k,t})\|^{2}\leq G for any ğ°,kâˆˆ[K],tâˆˆ[T]formulae-sequenceğ°ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡{\bf w},k\in[K],t\in[T]. As identified in SGD analysis of FL [10], this assumption makes the OL analysis simple but it can ignore the effect of data-heterogeneity. Instead, we introduce a more meaningful quantity (defined by Ïƒdiff2superscriptsubscriptğœdiff2\sigma_{\rm diff}^{2} in DefinitionÂ 1), which can capture the degree of data-heterogeneity over time and across decentralized clients. Based on our tighter regret analysis, we theoretically prove that OFedIQ over Tğ‘‡T time steps can achieve an optimal subliner regret ğ’ªâ€‹(Î±â€‹T)ğ’ªğ›¼ğ‘‡{\cal O}(\sqrt{\alpha T})) for any dataset, wherein the constant Î±>0ğ›¼0\alpha>0 relies on the degree of data-heterogeneity and the key parameters of the communication-reduction techniques (see Theorem 1 and Theorem 2). As expected, Î±ğ›¼\alpha tends to be bigger as data-heterogeneity (i.e., Ïƒdiff2superscriptsubscriptğœdiff2\sigma_{\rm diff}^{2}) grows. More importantly, our regret bound enables to optimize the key parameters of OFedIQ such as sampling rate, transmission period, and quantization levels (see SectionÂ 4.2).

Before stating the main results, we provide some useful notations and definitions. Let ğ°â‹†subscriptğ°â‹†{\bf w}_{\star} be the parameter of the best function in hindsight, i.e.,

Note that when quantization and periodic transmission are not used (i.e., Ïƒq2=0superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘20\sigma_{q}^{2}=0 and L=1ğ¿1L=1), the regret bound in Theorem 2 is not exactly matched with that in Theorem 1 although in this case, OFedIQ is reduced to OFedAvg. 4.2 Optimization of OFedIQ

Although the asymptotic optimality of OFedIQ is proved, it does not ensure the best performances of OFedIQ for real-world OFL tasks. Thus, on the basis of our regret analysis in SectionÂ 4.1, we further optimize the parameters of OFedIQ in Algorithm 2 such as sampling rate, transmission period, and quantization parameters. First we introduce a stochastic quantizer that will be used for our experiments in SectionÂ 5. This is an extension of the widely-used stochastic quantizer in [30, 11] by introducing the new parameter bğ‘b (see DefinitionÂ 2 for details), where the proposed quantizer with b=1ğ‘1b=1 is reduced to the existing one in [30, 11]. With the optimized parameters, it will be shown that the proposed quantizer in DefinitionÂ 2 can attain a non-trivial gain compared with the existing one.

5 Experiments

Via experiments with real datasets, we verify the analytical results in SectionÂ 4 and demonstrate the superiority of the optimized OFedIQ compared with the state-of-the-art OFL methods. Recall that using the stochastic quantizer in Definition 2, the proposed method is denoted by OFedIQ(L,p,s,b)ğ¿ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘(L,p,s,b), where Lğ¿L is the transmission period, pğ‘p is the sampling rate, and (s,b)ğ‘ ğ‘(s,b) is the parameter of the quantization. In convention, when quantization is not applied, it is denoted as OFedIQ(L,p,âˆ)ğ¿ğ‘(L,p,\infty). For comparison, the following benchmark methods are considered:

  • â€¢

    FedOGD [21]: This is the counterpart of FedSGD in FL. It is considered as the performance-limit of communication-efficient OFL methods.

  • â€¢

    OFedAvg(pğ‘p): This is the counterpart of FedAvg [6]. In this method, a smaller number of clients are participated at every time step (i.e., pâ€‹Kğ‘ğ¾pK in average).

  • â€¢

    FedOMD(Lğ¿L)[24]: This is the communication-efficient OFL method based on OMD and periodic transmission. In our experiments, a commonly adopted Euclidean distance is used as the underlying Bregman divergence of OMD.

To the best of our knowledge, there is no other OFL method with a performance guarantee. In fact, OFedIQ(L,p,s,b)ğ¿ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘(L,p,s,b) subsumes the benchmark methods as special cases. Nonetheless, it does not directly imply that OFedIQ can outperform them. Namely, the parameters should be optimized, which is efficiently performed via the proposed AlgorithmÂ 3 For a hyperparameter Î·ğœ‚\eta, it was proved in SectionÂ 4 that Î·=ğ’ªâ€‹(1/T)ğœ‚ğ’ª1ğ‘‡\eta={\cal O}(1/\sqrt{T}) is asymptotically optimal for the proposed and benchmark methods. In practice, however, it is generally unavailable to see the end-point of continuous streaming data (i.e., Tğ‘‡T) in advance. We set Î·=0.01ğœ‚0.01\eta=0.01 for all experiments, which is sufficient for their fair comparisons. As commonly adopted in online learning tasks [26, 27, 21], we use the following metric to assess learning accuracy:

To evaluate the communication-cost reduction (CCR) of the communication-efficient (CF) methods (OFedAvg, FedOMD, and OFedIQ) over the baseline method (FedOGD), the following metric is considered:

CCR(%)\displaystyle\mbox{CCR}(\%) =(1âˆ’Î³)Ã—100,absent1ğ›¾100\displaystyle=(1-\gamma)\times 100,

where Î³=communication-cost of CF-method32â€‹Kâ€‹Dğ›¾communication-cost of CF-method32ğ¾ğ·\gamma=\frac{\mbox{communication-cost of CF-method}}{32KD} as introduced in SectionÂ 4.2. One of the following model architectures will be adopted according to dataset:

  • â€¢

    Model I (CNN): This convolutional neural network (CNN) model consists of two convolutional layers (each with 323232 nodes and 646464 nodes), one softmax layer with 101010 nodes, and 333 bias nodes. Each convolutional layer is composed of multiple sequential operations including convolution, ReLU activation, and max-pooling. A cross-entropy loss function is used. This model contains the 109109109 nodes and accordingly, the number of parameters is equal to D=10Ã—32+289Ã—64+1601Ã—10=34,826formulae-sequenceğ·10322896416011034826D=10\times 32+289\times 64+1601\times 10=34,826.

  • â€¢

    Model II (DNN): This deep neural network (DNN) model consists of two ReLU layer with 646464 nodes, 3 bias nodes, and one softmax layer with 444 nodes. A cross-entropy loss function is considered. This model contains the overall 135135135 nodes and accordingly, the number of parameters is equal to D=2Ã—64+65Ã—64+65Ã—4=4,548formulae-sequenceğ·26465646544548D=2\times 64+65\times 64+65\times 4=4,548.

  • â€¢

    Model III (DNN): This deep neural network (DNN) model consists of two ReLU layer with 646464 nodes, one fc layer with 111 node, and 333 bias nodes. A regularized least-square loss function â„’â€‹(â‹…,â‹…)â„’â‹…â‹…{\cal L}(\cdot,\cdot) is used. This model contains the 132132132 nodes and accordingly, the number of parameters is equal to D=2Ã—64+65Ã—64+65Ã—1=4,353formulae-sequenceğ·26465646514353D=2\times 64+65\times 64+65\times 1=4,353.

In our experiments, the network has K=1000ğ¾1000K=1000 clients each receiving Tğ‘‡T data samples sequentially. The following real datasets are considered:

  • â€¢

    MNIST [32]: The dataset consists of 60,000 samples with 10 handwritten single digits. Each sample has 784 features. The goal is to classify a given handwritten digit into one of 10 classes (integer values from 0 to 9). Model I is used.

  • â€¢

    Room Occupancy Estimation [33]: This dataset contains 10,130 time-series samples with the four classes {0,1,2,3}0123\{0,1,2,3\}. Each sample has 14 features extracted from environmental sensors such as temperature, light, sound, CO2 and PIR. The goal is to predict the precise number of occupants in a room. Model II is used.

  • â€¢

    Air quality [34]: This dataset contains 38,563 time-series samples. Each sample has 5 features including hourly response from an array of 5 metal oxide chemical sensors embedded in a city of Italy. The goal is to estimate the concentration of polluting chemicals in the air. Model III is used.

  • â€¢

    Appliances energy [35]: This dataset contains 18,604 samples, each of which has 252525 features describing appliances energy uses such as temperature and pressure in houses. The goal is to predict energy use in a low-energy building. Model III is used.

For the case of Nb<1000â€‹Tsubscriptğ‘ğ‘1000ğ‘‡N_{b}<1000T, where Nbsubscriptğ‘ğ‘N_{b} denotes the number of whole data samples in a dataset, the entire samples are repeated by âŒŠ1000â€‹T/NbâŒ‹1000ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘ğ‘\lfloor 1000T/N_{b}\rfloor times. To study OFL, it is required to specify how data samples in each dataset are distributed across the 100010001000 clients. As in [6], random partitioning is performed, from which the entire 1000â€‹T1000ğ‘‡1000T data samples are shuffled and then partitioned into the K=1000ğ¾1000K=1000 clients. The resulting partition is denoted as {ğ’Ÿ1,â€¦,ğ’ŸK}subscriptğ’Ÿ1â€¦subscriptğ’Ÿğ¾\{{\cal D}_{1},...,{\cal D}_{K}\} with |ğ’Ÿk|=T,âˆ€kâˆˆ[K]formulae-sequencesubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘‡for-allğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾|{\cal D}_{k}|=T,\forall k\in[K]. At time step tğ‘¡t, each client kğ‘˜k receives the data (ğ±k,t,yk,t)subscriptğ±ğ‘˜ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜ğ‘¡({\bf x}_{k,t},y_{k,t}) from ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜{\cal D}_{k} sequentially. Although there are numerous partitions, our experiments confirmed that the performances of the proposed and benchmark methods are not affected by partitions as long as Tğ‘‡T is large. This coincides with our theoretical results as partitions do not change the degree of data-heterogeneity Ïƒdiffsubscriptğœdiff\sigma_{\rm diff}.

Performance evaluation: We first validate the analytical results in SectionÂ 4 via experiments with MNIST data. Fig.Â 2 manifests that L=1ğ¿1L=1 is the best choice for a fixed p/Lğ‘ğ¿p/L, which is well-matched with our analysis in SectionÂ 4.2.1. Specifically, the performance loss with L>1ğ¿1L>1 is noticeable in non-asymptotic case (e.g., t=200ğ‘¡200t=200), whereas it becomes negligible as tğ‘¡t is sufficiently large. Also, this loss becomes severer as Lğ¿L increases. Based on these results and our analysis in SectionÂ 4.2.1, to reduce the communication costs as intermittent transmission, client subsampling should be adopted rather than periodic transmission. FigÂ 3 shows the efficacy of the proposed parameter optimization in Algorithm 3. The optimized OFedIQ(1,0.086,3,777)10.0863777(1,0.086,3,777) outperforms OFedIQ with different parameters such as OFedIQ(1,0.086,7,1)10.08671(1,0.086,7,1) and OFedIQ(1,0.01,âˆ)10.01(1,0.01,\infty) (a.k.a. OFedAvg(0.01)0.01(0.01)), while having the same communication costs. To the best of our efforts, we could not find other OFedIQ showing better performance than the optimized OFedIQ. Compared with OFedIQ(1,0.086,7,1)10.08671(1,0.086,7,1), the optimized OFedIQ used the proposed stochastic quantization in Definition 2 rather than the stochastic quantization in [30, 11]. From Fig.Â 3, we can identify the effectiveness of the proposed stochastic quantizer. Moreover, the comparison with FedAvg demonstrates that quantization is indeed useful in order to reduce the communication costs considerably. This supports our theoretical analysis in SectionÂ 4.2.2.

Fig. 4 shows the performances of various OFL methods on regression and classification tasks with real datasets. As aforementioned, FedOGD is considered as the performance bound of the communication efficient OFL methods. Regarding the optimized OFedIQ(L,p,s,b)ğ¿ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘(L,p,s,b), L=1ğ¿1L=1 is chosen from SectionÂ 4.2.1, and pğ‘p and (s,b)ğ‘ ğ‘(s,b) are optimized via Algorithm 3. From Fig. 4, we observe that the optimized OFedIQ outperform the benchmark methods for all datasets. Remarkably, it can almost achieve the performance of FedOGD while reducing the communication costs by 99%percent9999\%. Interestingly, FedOMD, which reduces the communication costs via periodic transmission only, yields very poor performances especially when CCR=99%CCRpercent99\mbox{CCR}=99\%. This is because only a small number of global updates are performed. These results strengthen the argument in SectionÂ 4.2.1 that periodic transmission is not suitable for OFL. When CCR=90%CCRpercent90\mbox{CCR}=90\%, it seems that quantization is unnecessary since FedAvg has the same performance as the optimized OFedIQ. To further reduce the communication costs (e.g., CCR=99%CCRpercent99\mbox{CCR}=99\%), however, the optimized quantization is indeed effective. Thus, the optimized OFedIQ can provide a more elegant tradeoff of performance and communication costs than FedAvg. Our experimental results suggest the practicality of the optimized OFedIQ.

6 Conclusion

We presented a communication-efficient method (named OFedIQ) for online federated learning (OFL) by means of client subsampling, periodic transmission, and quantization. Through our tighter regret analysis, it was proved that OFedIQ can enjoy an optimal sublinear regret for any real dataset (up to a constant) while significantly reducing the communication costs of FedOGD (i.e., the performance-limit). On the basis of our analysis, moreover, we efficiently optimized the key parameters of OFedIQ such as the sampling rate, the transmission period, and quantization levels. Via experiments with real datasets, we demonstrated the effectiveness of our algorithm on various online classification and regression tasks. Specifically, for all datasets in our experiments, the optimized OFedIQ outperforms the state-of-the-art OFL methods. In addition, it can almost achieve the performances of FedOGD while reducing the communication costs by 99%percent9999\%. These results suggest the practicality of the optimized OFedIQ.
